chapter.title: Introducing &PRODUCT_BRAND;
chapter.para: &PB; is a bare-metal hypervisor that uses native hardware support for virtualization to enable near bare-metal performance. 3D graphics and multimedia performance is not compromised. The hypervisor component of the &PB; platform is a thin layer, just a few megabytes in size.

&PB; allows users to have a personal desktop image that is totally separated and completely isolated from a locked down corporate desktop image running on the same machine. The personal desktop gives the user the ability to install their own applications, while the corporate desktop image remains securely isolated and locked down, which results in a lower cost of operation and IT being able to provide higher service levels to their customers.
&BACKEND; provides VM imaging services to &PB;. It allows users to pull imaged VMs on to their &PB;-enabled machines, and also to sync their VMs back to &BACKEND;.
&PORTICA; technology allows users to access applications running in VMs other than that in which they are currently working.

chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: The &PB; software stack consists of four parts:

listitem.para: &PB; is a bare metal hypervisor that allows you to run multiple operating systems on a computer simultaneously.
&BACKEND; provisions, backs up and manages virtual machine (VM) images.
&DAZZLE; is an self-service application store.
&PORTICA; allows application windows to be shared between VMs running on the same computer.

chapter.para: Together, &PB;, &BACKEND;, &DAZZLE; and &PORTICA; provide the capacity to radically simplify the deployment and maintenance of desktops and applications to users in a way that provides secure computing and ease of use for users and administrators alike. By enabling multiple operating systems to be installed on a single computer and providing the ability to switch between running operating systems in real-time, a user can be provided with a single computer for both home and office use, with each operating system securely isolated from the other. Additionally, user data can be separated from system data, and the system data refreshed on a regular basis, ensuring the speed and great user experience of a fresh installation each day, and ease of patch deployment and operating system updates. &PB; differs from many other desktop virtualization schemes by preserving the graphics performance of the virtual machine most commonly used.

When it comes to applications, &PB; integrates with &DAZZLE; to allow users to pull the applications they want onto their computers without any intervention by systems administrators. The user can also leverage &PORTICA; to seamlessly share application windows between operating systems.

In short, &PB; and related technologies provide a safe, secure and simple way to provision and maintain applications and operating systems in the enterprise in a manner that combines maximum performance, cost effectiveness and ease of use.

section.title: &PB;
section.para: The &PB; software is based on bare-metal virtualization. It can be thought of as a software layer that acts as an intermediary between the operating systems (sometimes referred to as virtual machines or VMs) running on it and the physical hardware. This allows the user to run multiple VMs on a single computer simultaneously, and switch between them in real time. The operating systems are isolated from eachother, ensuring that a malicious piece of software that might infect one VM will not be able to infect any other VMs.

The hypervisor layer controls the resources of the physical machine (RAM, GPU, disk, and so on) so that all of the available computing power is made available to the VM that the user is currently using. This results in barely measurable performance impact.

&PB; management capabilities are provided by &BRAND_CONSOLE;. The &BRAND_CONSOLE; user interface is displayed after the &PB; software has been installed and the computer has rebooted. &BRAND_CONSOLE; guides the user or systems administrator through the process of installing VMs, either using physical vendor media or by downloading an image that a systems administrator has assigned to them using &BACKEND;. &BRAND_CONSOLE; also provides an easy to use network configuration utility and the ability to start, stop and suspend VMs, and interact with &BACKEND;.
&HDX; is a performance enhancement to permit a VM to avoid the overhead of virtualization for the graphics system.

At any given time, only one VM running on a machine can enjoy HDX 3D Graphics acceleration. If multiple VMs are enabled to use HDX 3D Graphics, only the first enabled VM started after the machine is booted will enjoy HDX 3D Graphics acceleration.

note.para: &HDX; will only be available once the &PV_TOOLS; have been installed on the VM.

section.title: &PB; networking
section.para: The XenClient platform allows the user to configure the wired network mode for each virtual machine independently. The preferred choice depends on network topology and user environment. Wireless connections will always be Shared Mode. The rest of this section presents the various networking modes.

section.title: Shared Mode
section.para:
By default all network connections are set to Shared Mode. The internal &PB; network architecture uses network address translation (NAT) to allow all virtual machines to share a single external wired or wireless network connection. Wired connections are allocated an IP address in the 172.16.25.x
range. Wired connections are allocated an IP address in the 172.16.26.x range.

section.title: Bridged Mode (Wired Network Connections only)
section.para: Bridged Network Connections will expose the virtual network interfaces on individual VMs to the physical Ethernet, allowing them to acquire an external IP Address from the network. Bridged mode is suitable in situations where you want to allow external systems to directly access services such as file or printer sharing within your virtual machine.

note.para: Bridged mode requires that each virtual NIC be configured appropriately. Either the physical network will have to provide DHCP to allow the interface to establish an IP address and associated configuration, or you will need to statically configure the network settings on that interface from within the virtual machine.

section.title: Internal
section.para: Internal Mode only allows network communication between VMs.

section.title: &BACKEND;
section.para: &BACKEND; manages and provisions VM images, called Desktops. Once a &PB; computer has registered with &BACKEND; users may:

listitem.para: Download VM images assigned to them by an administrator.
Upload a VM on their computer to &BACKEND;
Register it to be managed by &BACKEND;.
Backup their user data.
Receive regular system partition refreshes.

section.para: When a VM is registered with &BACKEND; as a managed appliance a copy of the original VM is created and made available for use in &BC;. The original VM may still be used but will not have any relationship with &BACKEND;.
A system administrator can use &BACKEND; to manage users, their desktops and devices.

section.title: &PORTICA; overview
section.para:
&PORTICA; enables a user to share application windows seamlessly between running Windows operating systems. Seamless application sharing between VMs is achieved using the proprietary &COMPANY_NAME_SHORT; ICA protocol. To enable seamless application sharing, the &PB; Seamless Application Sharing software must be installed on the VM that is going to share the application. Support for this software is included in the &PV_TOOLS;. Applications in the VM will be published through &DAZZLE;. See
for more details.

section.title: &DAZZLE; overview
section.para: &DAZZLE; provides users with self-service access to the applications and desktops they need to work productively. The easy-to-use &DAZZLE; interface allows users to subscribe to applications and desktops hosted on other &PB; VMs, XenApp and XenDesktop servers with a single click. Applications can be delivered to users in one of three ways. They can be:

listitem.para: Streamed to the user computer and installed so that it can be used when the user is offline.
Accessed online from XenApp or XenDesktop resources.

Locally installed and shared between VMs. In this case the application will be monitored when the user is online and reinstalled if the application gets corrupted or the systems administrator provides an updated version.

section.para: In all cases an application shortcut is placed on the user desktop or windows Start menu which starts an ICA session when double-clicked, causing the application to appear integrated on the user desktop.

For added security, although the application is shared, when an application is in focus the keystrokes and mouse movements are forwarded directly to the &PB; hypervisor and so that the VM that is displaying the application is never aware of them.

section.title: Hardware requirements
section.para: &PB; runs on 64bit platforms only. The hardware requirements are:

listitem.para: Intel Core 2 Duo Processor
1GB of memory (1 XP Instance) minimum
2GB RAM or greater recommended
160GB disk space or greater recommended
Intel Integrated Graphics 400MHD
Management - Intel vPro

chapter.title: Installation Overview
chapter.para: To install &PB; and take advantage of &PORTICA; and the &BACKEND; provisioning services, perform the following steps.

step.para: Install and setup &BACKEND;. See for information about how to do this.
Install the &PB; software on one of the supported machines. See for information on how to do this.
In &BC;, create a VMs with &HDX_FIRST; enabled. For information about how to do this, see .
In &BC; create a second VM that does not have &HDX; enabled. For information about how to do this, see for information about how to do this.
Install &PORTICA;. See for information about how to do this.
Ensure that the hardware has the correct BIOS settings. To do this:

procedure.title: Preparing a Lenovo T400 for installation

step.para: Press the blue ThinkVantage button, F1 while the machine is booting.

Set Config > CPU > Intel Virtualisation Technology to Enabled
.

Set Config > CPU > Intel VT-d feature to Enabled
.
Move the wireless switch to the rightmost position (green).
Disable AMT on the T400.

procedure.title: Preparing a Dell E6400 or E4300 for installation

step.para: Press F12, select BIOS, while the machine is booting.

Set Wireless > Wi-Fi Catcher to Disabled
.

Set Virtualisation Support > Virtualisation > Enable Intel Virtualization Technology
.

Set Virtualisation Support > VT for Direct I/O > Enable VT for Direct I/O
.
Move the wireless switch towards the screen (red).
Press Esc, F10, while the machine is booting.

Set System Configuration > Device Configuration > Virtualization Technology > Enabled
.
Press the WiFi icon so it changes colour from red to blue.
Ensure that you have BIOS version F.12 or later.

note.para: Disable TPM (Trusted Platform Module) and TXT (Trusted Execution Technology) for all models.

section.title: Networking
section.para:
&PB; uses the open-source NetworkManager
to provide network management functionality in &BC;, which allows you to connect to other computers and to the internet. See the documentation
of NetworkManager for more information about setting up networking using NetworkManager.

note.para: Whatever networks you setup in &BC; will be made available to all VMs, including the Wireless network which is shared between all VMs using Network Address Translation (NAT).

step.para: NetworkManager will automatically connect to the wired network and acquire an IP address with DHCP when an ethernet cable is plugged in.

procedure.title: Creating a VM from vendor media

step.para: In the &IOVM; click Create VM.
Click the Create New from Vendor Media button. The Create a New Virtual Machine wizard is displayed.
Select the operating system type from the Type dropdown list.
Enter a short name for the VM, and optionally its description. Select an icon to represent the VM. The short name and the icon will be used to distinguish VMs in the toolbar.
Click Next.
Choose the amount of RAM to assign to the VM. The default of 1024Mb is appropriate for Windows Vista and Windows 7. For Windows XP, 512Mb is generally adequate.
Click the Next button to go to the next step of the wizard.

Specify the size of the virtual disk to assign to the VM. The actual disk space used by a virtual disk reflects how much data has been written to it, and so may be considerably less than the size you specify.
Select the wired network mode. The options are:

listitem.para: Bridged which is suitable in situations where you want to allow external systems to directly access services such as file or printer sharing within your virtual machine. The Virtual NIC within the VM is bridged to the physical network. Incoming connections to your VM are enabled.

Shared which places your Virtual NIC on a private network on the XenClient system and allows outgoing connections using NAT (network address translation). In this case you will not be able to allow incoming connections to your virtual machine.
Internal which only allows for network communication between VMs.

step.para: Click Next

From the XenClient Tools menu, select Attached. This causes the &PV_TOOLS; to be mounted as an extra optical disk drive in the VM. This option may also be used by system integrators to attach arbitrary optical disk images in ISO9660 format, such as OS install disks.
If you select Start virtual machine automatically, this VM will be started automatically shortly after the &PB; platform boots. The VM will receive the display focus instead of the &IOVM;.
Click the Finish button.
Insert the operating system installation media into the optical drive of the machine.

Select the VM from the list, and click the Start button. If necessary, press the VM hotkey that is displayed in the UI. The VM will take focus. Complete the operating system installation as you would do on any other physical machine.

note.para: Do not enable automatic Windows updates until you have installed the &PV_TOOLS;.

step.para: When installation is complete, install the &PV_TOOLS; by running setup.exe from the optical disk (conventionally mounted as D:). This installs high performance virtualization aware drivers and an easy to use VM Switcher bar to allow switching between the VMs.
Download and install the latest graphics and audio drivers.

section.para: VMs may be downloaded and uploaded to the &BACKEND;. In &PB;, causing a VM to be uploaded is termed Publishing. Users may download managed VMs provided by the administrators of the &BACKEND;. To interact with the &BACKEND;, a &PB; instance must be Registered.

Enter your &BACKEND; username and password and click the Next
button.

Download and install the latest graphics drivers.

chapter.title: &DAZZLE; and &PORTICA;
chapter.para: All applications, including those that originate from &DAZZLE;, can be shared seamlessly between VMs. What this amounts to in practise is that an application running on a VM is displayed in another VM, and appears and can interacted with as if it was running in that VM.

From a security point of view, although the application is shared, keystrokes and mouse movements are forwarded directly to the &PB; hypervisor and the VM that is displaying the application is never aware of them. Also, the VM that is actually running the application is simply sending the graphical display via the &PB; hypervisor.

warning.para: Please ensure that you have installed all available Windows updates before installing &PORTICA;.

step.para: Ensure that the &PV_TOOLS; are installed on each VM you wish to use with &PORTICA;.
Ensure that you have selected Attached for the XenClient Tools option in VM details, for the VM you wish to use to display Seamless applications.
Boot the VM if it is not already running.
Open the Seamless directory in the attached &PV_TOOLS; optical disk.
Double-click to install Receiver.
Double-click to install CitrixOnlinePluginFull.
Double-click to install Dazzle.
Verify the installation by browsing the list of applications in the Dazzle Apps section of the Start menu.

chapter.title: &BACKEND;
chapter.para: &BACKEND; is the central backend management service that allows you to create virtual images, manage virtual image deployments and configure user access. This chapter explains the key concepts involved in working with &BACKEND;.

section.title: Devices
section.para: A device is a computer that has the &PB; hypervisor installed on it. A device is registered with a &BACKEND;. &BACKEND; maintains asset records of the device, and credentials are retained to allow secure communication between the device and &BACKEND;.

section.title: Users
section.para: A user is assigned one or more &PB;-based devices. &BACKEND;. A registered device is bound to a specific user, allowing that user to install VMs on the device. The system facilitates large-scale management of users and devices.

section.title: Desktops
section.para: An desktop is a template of a VM that can be installed onto devices. Desktops are composed of:

listitem.para: Image files stored in the Microsoft Virtual Hard Disk (VHD) format. &PB; makes use of VHD chaining to allow VHDs to be used as gold masters, where a single large VHD may act as a parent to a large set of copy on write (CoW) children. This approach is also used to efficiently store subsequent versions of VM image files and backups of user data.

Policy and configuration describing how the VM should act when it is deployed on the client device. This information includes details such as whether the VM is allowed to use USB devices, or whether it can share a unified copy and paste buffer (clipboard) with other VMs.

section.para:
Desktops are versioned. &BACKEND; hosts multiple
immutable versions of an desktop. New versions are generated when changes are made to an desktop image. An administrator can, for example, create a new desktop containing a simple Windows XP installation and publish this from &BACKEND; as version 1. They can later take the image, install some new software and release it as version 2. &PB; manages deploying this update to users.

section.title: Publications
section.para: Publications are relationships between specific desktop versions and specific users or groups of users. A publication allows a user to instantiate a specific desktop version on their device. When connected to &BACKEND; users can request a list of available desktops, which is provided by querying for desktop versions that have been published to that user.

By publishing specific versions of desktops to users, &PB;
allows new versions to be tested on specific (small) groups of
users before being widely published. This also allows updates to
desktop versions to be staged across different groups of users.
Using &PB; with &BACKEND; involves the four stages described below to create new desktop VMs, and deploy them onto client devices.

&PB; supports two types of desktops, private mode and shared mode. Private mode desktops are desktop images that are managed centrally and deployed to users, but the images are not updated over time. Deployed images can, however, be transparently backed up to &BACKEND; to ensure that data on devices remains protected.

Shared mode desktops isolate user data from the system disk of the desktop VM. The system disk is reset to a known-good configuration on reboot. Shared mode desktops allow administrators to "patch" desktop VMs, installing new versions of software, for instance, and push these patches out to &PB; users in the background.

To begin using &BACKEND;, you should first have at least one &PB; notebook configured, and have installed at least one desktop VM from vendor media that you would like to share with other &PB;-based notebooks in your organization. Refer to for details on how to install the client software and VMs.

section.title: Managing desktops using &BACKEND;
section.para:
&BACKEND; is responsible for managing the deployment of a set of independently authored desktop VM images (or desktops) to a large number of users, each with one or more &PB; devices. As devices may be lost or stolen, it also provides facilities to protect data (such as backup), and support for tracking device hardware assets that are owned by the organization. To achieve these goals, XenClient devices can operate in one of three modes: Unregistered, Registered
,and Bound to a specific user.

Breaking this process into three stages has a number of benefits. Firstly, &PB; may run as a stand-alone client virtualization platform in unregistered mode with no requirement to deploy a &BACKEND; instance.

Second, registration, which allows device hardware to be tracked using lightweight asset-management support in &BACKEND;, can be performed at installation time, and is decoupled from a user interacting with the device. An IT administrator may then receive shipment of, and register, a group of new notebooks with &BACKEND; before giving them out to users, and may tag the group with an invoice number that describes the order. In the future, this registration stage will be extended to allow client devices to be preloaded with common gold master VM images while they are connected on a high-speed corporate network, prior to them being given to users who may then log in from outside the enterprise.

Finally, the binding stage of &PB; devices establishes a permanent link between that installation of &PB; on that piece of hardware, and a specific user. Once bound to a user, the &BC; interface will display the list of desktop VMs that have been assigned to that user as available for installation. VMs may be backed up to &BACKEND; in the background, and associated with that specific user. In the event that a device is lost, backups of a user's VMs may be used to recover their &PB; installation on a new computer.

chapter.title: Installing &BACKEND;
chapter.para: &BACKEND; provides user and desktop provisioning services to &PB; users. &BACKEND; also provides a user interface for managing users, virtual desktops and devices.

&BACKEND; is provided as a XenServer Virtual Appliance (XVA) file. &BACKEND; is based on a virtual machine template that does not require any installation procedures and can be imported into any XenServer 5.5 environment. To use &BACKEND; you need to deploy a XenServer installation onto a new physical server. Alternately you can use an existing XenServer 5.5 installation.

step.para: Download the &BACKEND; appliance from the &COMPANY_NAME_SHORT; website.
The compressed archive contains a .xva file. Uncompress the file and double-click on it to import it into XenCenter.
Create a new VM from the imported template by double-clicking on the template in XenCenter and completing the steps of the New VM wizard. See the XenCenter online help for assistance if required.

Configure your network to assign the IP or hostname to this virtual machine that you intend to be visible in URLs that will be used by &PB; users and administrators. By default, the system will use whatever numeric IP address is assigned to the host by DHCP. If you desire to configure your DNS to assign a hostname to the &BACKEND; VM, do that now.
Once the VM is booted, log into the VM using the XenCenter console, with the username root and you will be prompted to set a password for this account. The &BACKEND; installer is displayed.

Configure the installer according to your environment. &COMPANY_NAME_SHORT; recommends that you enable mount permissions for the webserver user. This is enabled by default and is controlled the Give Mount Privileges

chapter.title: &BACKEND; Administration
chapter.para: This chapter contains the procedures required for administering &BACKEND;, using the web-based &BACKEND; UI, which can be accessed by pointing a web browser at the &BACKEND; server URL. The steps involved in making a VM image available to a user are:

listitem.para: Use a web browser to access the URL reported by &BACKEND; in the XenCenter console, and log in as admin with the password admin.

In the &BACKEND; UI, create an activation ID. This ID identifies one or many computers. The activation ID is entered on a &PB; computer either during installation of when first attempting to connect to &BACKEND;. &BACKEND; then automatically registers the computer in the &BACKEND; database.
Create a user using the &BACKEND; interface.
Use &BC; to create the VM.

Using &BC;, publish an existing VM to &BACKEND; by clicking the Publish Desktop
button.
Click the Publish Transmitter Desktop button, and log in as the user created in the first step. The VM starts to upload to &BACKEND;.
Once the VM upload is complete, use &BACKEND; to deploy desktop instances to users.

On the Devices tab, scroll down to the Device Activation Batches
section and click New. The Create New Activation

Enter an activation ID and a description. The activation ID can be anything.
Create and select Tags to identify this activation, or this batch of activations.
Click the Create button.
Click the Close button.

.

Enter the user details.

procedure.title: Assigning a desktop to a user
procedure.para:
Once a VM has been published to &BACKEND;, it is shown in the Desktops
tab. You can now assign this desktop to users, which allows them to install it on their devices.

step.para: On the Desktops tab, use the Search box to find the desktop you want to publish, then double click it to view its details in a new tab.
Select the version to be published, and click the Assign button.
A dialog box is displayed with the desktop and version that you have selected. Choose the user that you would like to assign it to, and customize the configuration or policy settings.

Click the Assign button to assign the desktop to a user. The new assignment appears in the Desktop Assignment
table.
